case_name: Dr. Gopal Das Varma v. Dr. Bhardwaj

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 278 of 1959 filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 278 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 2, 1957 of Punjab High Court in Civil Revision No. 239 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 2, 1957, of the Punjab High Court, in Civil

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 2, 1961 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. May 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The appellant Dr. Gopal Das

facts.text: Appellant Dr. Gopal Das Varma owns double-storeyed house at 28, Barakhamba Road, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Dr. Gopal Das Varma owns a double-storeyed house known as 28, Barakhamba Road, New Delhi.

facts.text: In October 1953, appellant sued respondents for ejectment under s.13(1)(e) and s.13(1)(h) of Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952.

issues.text: Whether premises let for residential purposes but used by the tenant for professional purposes with the landlord's consent qualify as residential premises under s.13(1)(e) and its explanation for eviction on ground of bona fide need?

anchor.surface_text: It would be noticed that as soon as it is found that the premises in question have been used by respondent 1 incidentally for professional purposes and it is further established that this use is made with the companysent of the landlord then the case goes outside the purview of s. 13 1  e altogether. In the present case it has been found by the appellate Court and the High Court that right from the companymencement of the tenancy a substantial part of the premises is used by respondent 1 for his professional purpose, and they have also found that this has been done obviously with the companysent of the landlord.

issues.text: Whether the landlord can obtain eviction under s.13(1)(h) if the tenant has built or acquired a suitable residence, when the subject premises are used both for residence and profession?
Whether premises let for combined residential and professional use fall within the definition of 'premises' under s.2(g) of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Faced with this difficulty the learned Solicitor-General attempted to argue that the very finding made by the Courts below about the nature of the tenancy takes the premises outside the purview of s. 2 g of the Act. The argument is that the premises cannot then be said to have been let for use as a residence or for a commercial use and so they ceased to be premises under the Act.

issues.text: Whether the respondent is estopped by the principle of approbate and reprobate from contending that the premises were let for residence and profession, based on prior conduct?
Whether a new plea requiring evidence, such as approbate and reprobate, can be raised for the first time in an appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution?

arguments.claim: New pleas requiring evidence not allowed in Art.136 appeals

holdings.text: Premises let for residential purposes but used by tenant incidentally for professional purposes with landlord's consent cease to be residential premises under s.13(1)(e) and landlord cannot eject even on proof of bona fide need.

anchor.surface_text: It would be noticed that as soon as it is found that the premises in question have been used by respondent 1 incidentally for professional purposes and it is further established that this use is made with the consent of the landlord then the case goes outside the purview of s. 13 1  e altogether. In the present case it has been found by the appellate Court and the High Court that right from the commencement of the tenancy a substantial part of the premises is used by respondent 1 for his professional purpose, and they have also found that this has been done obviously with the consent of the landlord. It is unnecessary to refer to the evidence on which this finding is based.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets explanation to s.13(1)(e) literally; accepts appellate and High Court findings on substantial professional use with consent since tenancy commencement.

holdings.text: Premises let for combined residence and professional use are still 'premises' under s.2(g) as 'any other purpose' includes combination of residence and commerce.

anchor.surface_text: Faced with this difficulty the learned Solicitor-General attempted to argue that the very finding made by the Courts below about the nature of the tenancy takes the premises outside the purview of s. 2 g  of the Act. The argument is that the premises cannot then be said to have been let for use as a residence or for a commercial use and so they ceased to be premises under the Act. It is suggested that any other use which is specified by s. 2 g  would not include a combination of residence with commercial or professional purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.2(g); 'any other purpose' encompasses combined uses; consistent with Act's schedule divisions.

holdings.text: s.13(1)(h) does not apply to tenancies for combined residential and professional use merely because tenant acquires suitable residence, as new premises must suit both purposes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual reading of s.13(1)(h); requires suitable alternative for all tenancy purposes, not just residence; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: Tenant not estopped by approbate and reprobate from asserting combined use tenancy based on prior conduct, as conduct of both parties inconsistent and plea not raised earlier.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Both parties' conduct actuated by self-interest; plea requires evidence not adduced earlier.

holdings.text: New pleas requiring evidence, such as approbate and reprobate based on prior conduct, cannot be raised for first time in special leave appeals under Art.136.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled practice of Supreme Court; no opportunity for respondent to lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It would be noticed that as soon as it is found that the premises in question have been used by respondent 1 incidentally for professional purposes and it is further established that this use is made with the consent of the landlord then the case goes outside the purview of s. 13 1  e altogether. In the present case it has been found by the appellate Court and the High Court that right from the commencement of the tenancy a substantial part of the premises is used by respondent 1 for his professional purpose, and they have also found that this has been done obviously with the consent of the landlord. It is unnecessary to refer to the evidence on which this finding is based.
That is the view taken by the High Court and we see numberreason to differ from the companyclusion of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Faced with this difficulty the learned Solicitor-General attempted to argue that the very finding made by the Courts below about the nature of the tenancy takes the premises outside the purview of s. 2 g  of the Act. The argument is that the premises cannot then be said to have been let for use as a residence or for a commercial use and so they ceased to be premises under the Act. It is suggested that any other use which is specified by s. 2 g  would not include a combination of residence with commercial or professional purposes.
That is the view taken by the High Court and we see numberreason to differ from the companyclusion of the High Court.
